sect1.title: Status Page
sect1.para: This page provides information on the setup and contents of the FPM status page. See also fpm_get_status.

sect2.title: Configuration
sect2.para: The FPM status page can be enabled by setting the pm.status_path configuration parameter in the FPM pool configuration.

caution.para: For security the FPM status page should be restricted to internal requests or known client IPs only as the page reveals request URLs and information about available resources.

sect2.para: Depending on the web server configuration it might be needed to configure the web server to allow requests directly to this path, bypassing any PHP scripts. An example of a configuration for Apache with FPM listening on UDS and pm.status_path set to /fpm-status would look like:

After reloading or restarting both FPM and the web server the status page will be accessible from the browser (as long as the request comes from an allowed IP address if the IP restriction was configured).

sect2.title: Query Parameters
sect2.para: The format of the status page output can be altered by specifying one of the following query parameters:
Additional information can also be returned using the full query parameter.

simplelist.member: https://localhost/fpm-status - Brief output in the default text format
https://localhost/fpm-status?full - Full output in the default text format
https://localhost/fpm-status?json - Brief output in JSON format
https://localhost/fpm-status?html&full - Full output in HTML format

sect2.title: Displayed Information
sect2.para: Date/Time values use the unix timestamp format in JSON and XML output, otherwise they use the format resulting in the following example date "03/Jun/2021:07:21:46 +0100".

table.title: Basic information - Always displayed on the status page

row.entry: The name of the FPM process pool.
The process manager type - static, dynamic or ondemand.
The date/time that the process pool was last started.
The time in seconds since the process pool was last started.
The total number of accepted connections.
The number of requests (backlog) currently waiting for a free process.
The maximum number of requests seen in the listen queue at any one time.
The maximum allowed size of the listen queue.
The number of processes that are currently idle (waiting for requests).
The number of processes that are currently processing requests.
The current total number of processes.
The maximum number of concurrently active processes.
Has the maximum number of processes ever been reached? If so the displayed value is 1 otherwise the value is 0.
The total number of requests that have hit the configured request_slowlog_timeout.

table.title: Per-process information - only displayed in full output mode

row.entry: The system PID of the process.
The state of the process - Idle, Running, ...
The date/time at which the process started.
The number of seconds since the process started.
The total number of requests served.
The total time in seconds spent serving requests.
The HTTP method of the last served request.
The URI of the last served request (after webserver processing, it may always be /index.php if you use a front controller pattern redirect).
The length of the request body, in bytes, of the last request.
The HTTP user (PHP_AUTH_USER) of the last request.
The full path of the script executed by the last request. This will be '-' if not applicable (eg. status page requests).
The %cpu of the last request. This will be 0 if the process is not Idle because the calculation is done when the request processing is complete.
The maximum amount of memory consumed by the last request. This will be 0 if the process is not Idle because the calculation is done when the request processing is complete.

note.para: All values are specific to the pool and are reset when FPM is restarted.
OpenMetrics format output uses different parameter types to better suit the OpenMetrics format. The parameters and descriptions of their values are included in the OpenMetrics format output.
